description: 5.56x45mm ammunition with a 55gr jacketed boat tailed bullet.  5.56 ammunition has been very popular with civilian shooters for several decades, finding use in a wide variety of weapons.  The combination of high velocity with a thinly-jacketed, cannelured projectile led to unexpected yaw and fragmentation in soft tissue, increasing this round's performance.

5.56x45mm ammunition, loaded for precision from the Mk 12 SPR rifles, and later used by other SF units looking for more effective loadings for their M4A1 and Mk 18 carbines.  The Mk 262 Mod 1 is loaded with a 77gr Open Tip Match bullet, enhancing lethality even at longer ranges when compared to older M855 loadings.

5.56x45mm Mk 318 ammunition, developed due to SOF dissatisfaction with the M855 cartridge.  The Mk 318 Mod 1 is loaded with a 62gr Open Tip Match Rear Penetrator bullet, a copper slug enclosed inside an open-tipped brass projectile, providing for consistent loading, enhanced lethality and increased penetration.  When compared to M855, the Mk 318 fragments consistently, even out of short-barreled carbines.

5.56x45mm ammunition with a 62gr full metal jacket bullet containing a steel penetrator.  Originally designed for the M249 FN Minimi, M855 was designed to penetrate steel helmets and light cover at range, sacrificing terminal performance and accuracy in the process.  The limited yaw and fragmentation is worsened with shorter-barreled carbines shooting this round, and optimization of barrel twist for stabilization of the tracer variant of M855 has resulted in lackluster accuracy overall.

An updated loading of M855 5.56x45mm ammunition, featuring a 62gr projectile containing an exposed steel penetrator and copper slug.  Designed as a mostly lead-free projectile, the opportunity was further taken to improve upon M855's penetration and lethality characteristics through penetrator design and increased pressure.  Its improved accuracy, penetration and lethality over M855 are appreciated by users of shorter-barreled AR variants.

An M856 tracer round, loaded with a 64gr full metal jacket tracer bullet.  Traditional practice is to load one tracer per every four normal rounds to help keep the weapon they are fired from on target.  Tracers have the potential to ignite flammable substances at their point of impact.

5.56x45mm ammunition with a 55gr jacketed boat tailed bullet.  5.56 been very popular with civilian shooters for several decades, finding use in a wide variety of weapons.  Someone was down on their luck when they handloaded this one - it's filled with black powder instead of smokeless powder.  Expect lower velocity, muzzle smoke, and a dirtier barrel if you shoot it.

5.56x45mm ammunition with a 62gr full metal jacket bullet containing a steel penetrator.  Someone was down on their luck when they handloaded this one - it's filled with black powder instead of smokeless powder.  Expect lower velocity, muzzle smoke, and a dirtier barrel if you shoot it.

An M856 tracer round, loaded with a 64gr lead core projectile.  Traditional practice is to load one tracer per every four normal rounds to help keep the weapon they are fired from on target.  Someone was down on their luck when they hand-reloaded this one - it's filled with black powder instead of smokeless powder.  Expect lower velocity, muzzle smoke, and a dirtier barrel if you shoot it.  Tracers have the potential to ignite flammable substances at their point of impact.

5.56x45mm ammunition with a 55gr jacketed boat tailed bullet.  5.56 ammunition has been very popular with civilian shooters for several decades, finding use in a wide variety of weapons.  This one has been hand-reloaded by a survivor or perhaps a pre-Cataclysm hobbyist, leading to slightly inferior performance compared to factory-produced ammo.

5.56x45mm ammunition with a 62gr full metal jacket bullet.  This one has been hand-reloaded by a survivor or perhaps a pre-Cataclysm hobbyist, leading to slightly inferior performance compared to factory-produced ammo.

An M856 tracer round, loaded with a 64gr lead core projectile.  Traditional practice is to load one tracer per every four normal rounds to help keep the weapon they are fired from on target.  This one has been hand-reloaded by a survivor or perhaps a pre-Cataclysm hobbyist, leading to slightly inferior performance compared to factory-produced ammo.  Tracers have the potential to ignite flammable substances at their point of impact.
